items.title: Thursday Night Board Gaming @ Kangaroo and Kiwi
items.description: Let's meet up and play games. All are welcome and all games are welcome. Come early or late as we start off with short games then regroup into longer ones. We will have games, but you can bring your favorites to share also. We typically play light to medium weight games at this Meetup, but all games are welcome, assuming you have willing participants. If host(s) are late, anybody can lead with their game or grab some food and chat with others. Please note:Sometimes Kangaroo and Kiwi will be closed unexpectedly or rent out the big room. If this is the case, our backup venue is The Ballard Smoke Shop at 5439 Ballard Ave NW. Don't be fooled by the name, they are a restaurant & bar!

items.title: Beer & Code
items.location: Stoup Brewing - Capitol Hill, Seattle, WA
items.description: Come chat about something you've found interesting lately, work on a side project, read a book, whatever your fancy but it'll be very casual. Stoup Capitol Hill is a local brewery with a wide range of taps, some hard seltzers, a non-alcoholic seltzer and regular water. They don't sell food but you can bring any food in from the outside and there's normally a food truck outside.

items.title: Erin Go Hike... and Beer in Bellevue (Slainte!)
items.description: Happy St. Paddy's Day! Let's celebrate with a hike and a pint. We are going off-book again for this one since the weather can make some of the drives out of the area dodgy. We'll be hiking at Coal Creek Trail in Bellevue and raising a glass at Chainline Taproom in Kirkland. (Sorry...I'm not brave enough to try to get us all into an Irish Pub on the 17th!) The hike is 5 miles out-and-back (so will be hard for us to get lost lol) It's considered a moderate hike with a couple good up and down hills (567 ft elevation gain) -- and it can get muddy, so plan accordingly. As always, well socialized, leashed dogs (and Leprechauns) are welcome on the trail. (I'm checking on brewery rules for pups.) And, of course...if you get waitlisted for the hike, feel free to join us at the brewery for a beer around 12:30. +11

group_title: Bellevue Seattle Park Walks and Hikes

items.title: Friday Nights at Stoup
items.location: Stoup Brewing - Capitol Hill, Seattle, WA
items.description: Come play board games with us on Friday nights at Stoup Brewery. We play all sorts of games, ranging from party games to social deduction games to strategy games. If you're new to the board game, don't worry we'll teach you the rules. Bringing your own games is encouraged too. There will be a reservation for 20 people starting from 7pm. That's the largest size we can get without paying but generally there are more tables available. Also don't forget to support Stoup. This meetup is made possible by their venue. Thank you. +1

items.title: Dry Run - Momentum and Cadence
items.description: How long is too long to follow up with someone you met? When is too soon? Let's explore how to keep the momentum going after a positive interaction. We'll explore the analogy of having fun on a swing. A little push gets you swinging. With the right timing, additional little pushes get you swinging even higher. It's the same in budding friendships. Following up at the right time can build or maintain the momentum. We'll focus on applying this to a single instance of spending time with someone, focusing on how to create more momentum with light, low pressure invitations. From engaging in new topics in a conversation, to going for a walk after having a meal, or going for a meal after an activity, all these moments give us a chance to "push the swing" together to build more momentum in the friendship This is a "dry run" event. It's one of the first times we're hosting it. Expect some things to be bumpy or unrefined until we figure out the best format for this event. Feedback and suggestions are very welcome. +9

items.title: Talking and Active Listening
items.description: Let's practice active listening. Talking to an active listener makes it a lot easier to talk about yourself. So the sneaky second goal is to practice talking about yourself. Active Listening shows your conversation partner that you're with them. This makes talking to you more natural and enjoyable. We will review some common things people might do in order to try to connect that unfortunately have the opposite effect. The majority of the event will be spent practicing specific active listening skills in short conversations. This is a "dry run" event. It's one of the first times we're hosting it. Expect some things to be bumpy or unrefined until we figure out the best format for this event. Feedback and suggestions are very welcome. +3

items.title: Dry Run - Discovering Points of Connection
items.description: Let's figure out what we're looking for, what we're open to and what we have to offer and use it gently steer conversations towards potential points of connection. We will start by taking an inventory of our relationships and identifying the areas we're looking to add to our life. We will briefly discuss close relationships (romantic partnerships, support networks) but focus primarily on lighter forms of friendship (companions, activity buddies, potential close friends). It helps to know what you have room for in your life. Second, we'll spend sometime discovering the intersection between what we have to offer (skills, experiences, expertise) and what we want to offer. These will usually be passions or interests and will serve as potential points of connection. Finally, we will practice gently weaving in our interests, passions, and other potential points of connection into conversations. We will do this by mentioning these things without diving into too much detail, so that our conversation partner can choose to follow up if they are curious, interested or experienced in that area, without cornering them or over sharing if they're not. This is a "dry run" event. It's one of the first times we're hosting it. Expect some things to be bumpy or unrefined until we figure out the best format for this event. Feedback and suggestions are very welcome. +1

items.title: Conversation Cafe
items.description: What if we took over a coffee shop and filled it with friendly people looking to have conversations? ... where you knew for certain you wouldn't be interrupting if you asked to join them at their table. In fact, you would have probably made their day. Join us as we take over Ada's Technical Books & Cafe to practice socializing without worrying about messing up. All levels of social skills are welcome. Expect some awkward pauses, running out of things to say and feeling flustered. But also don't be surprised to find yourself in a state of flow, laughing and experiencing moments of unexpected joy from connecting in a conversation. We'll get things started with a quick warmup, an easy way to start a conversation and an easy way to wrap it up. After that will be free conversation time. You chose whom you'd like to talk to. When you're done chatting, you can head back to the starting area to let people know you're free and ready to chat or head to the rest area if you need a break. We will occasionally invite everyone to wrap up their current conversations and find new partners, so that you get to practice with multiple people. This is open to all. If you have been coming to the workshops, this can be a great place practice what you've learned. If you haven't, then come hang out with us, whether you're a pro speaker or someone looking to meet new people in a low pressure environment. This is a "dry run" event. It's one of the first times we're hosting it. Expect some things to be bumpy or unrefined until we figure out the best format for this event. Feedback and suggestions are very welcome.

items.title: Leading the Conversation
items.description: Let's practice talking with shy people and anxious people. In this session you'll partner with someone roleplaying a shy person that wants to talk to you but keeps running out of things to say. By taking charge and leading the conversation, you'll make the experience much more fun for both of you and face some of your own insecurities about these potentially awkward situations. Then we'll switch to roleplaying and anxious person that can't stop talking. The more they talk, the more they worry and the more they worry the more they talk. The way to help here is to interrupt and contribute to the conversation. It's going to feel like getting onto an escalator or those crazy elevators that don't have doors and don't stop on the floors. Expect these exercises to bring up some insecurities. You might feel like you are making the shy partner uncomfortable or that you're being rude to the anxious partner. Rest assured that being able to handle these situations better will make things more comfortable for you and your conversation partners in the future. This is a "dry run" event. It's one of the first times we're hosting it. Expect some things to be bumpy or unrefined until we figure out the best format for this event. Feedback and suggestions are very welcome.

items.title: Dry Run - Coffee, Meals and Walks
items.description: What do meeting up for coffee, sitting down for a meal at a restaurant or going on a walk in the park have in common? They're all one-on-one interactions where almost all of the attention is on you. They're easy to schedule and plan, but when following up with a new acquaintance for the first time, they require a higher level of comfort with talking and rejection. We'll start by reviewing our top one or two favorite coffee shops, casual dining places and parks. If you don't have one, you'll be invited to make a short list of places to explore in your area. Having places you enjoy in mind will make it that much less stressful to invite someone out to continue getting to know them. We'll then spend some time exploring the seemingly innocent yet sometimes intimidating "tell me a little about yourself". We'll practice responding in a way that invites people to follow up on things you care about while acknowledging but drawing attention away from things people commonly pry into but that have little to do with how you are. Finally we'll practice asking and answering the question in one on one practice. Remember to express interest and ask follow up questions, even if you're the one being invited to talk. Many people are secretly hoping that you'll ask them about themselves and sincerely listen to what they have to say. This is a "dry run" event. It's one of the first times we're hosting it. Expect some things to be bumpy or unrefined until we figure out the best format for this event. Feedback and suggestions are very welcome. 1 attendee 1 attendee

items.title: Dry Run - Facing Rejection
items.description: Rejection sucks. Let's get better with it. Rejection is an inevitable part of social interaction. If you put yourself out there, you will eventually experience people avoiding eye contact or making up an excuse to walk away from an interaction. You're not going to be everybody's cup of tea. Even if you were, they may have something else on their mind. None of this is news to anyone. That doesn't make it hurt any less. Most trainings I've attended have dealt with this by saying "don't let it bother you" and "the more you avoid it, the more sensitive you will become" with the ultimate solution being to "just do it anyway". That takes a tremendous amount of willpower and courage. It's valid, but has the potential to make things worse if they go poorly. We don't have to be so extreme. In this session, we will roleplay scenarios where you personally would chose to reject someone that was approaching you. By practicing rejecting, we hope to loosen up some of feelings of injustice that we might feel when we get rejected. You will have a choice about whether you want to participate in the exercises and at what intensity. We will only stick to the types of rejection you'd face as a mild mannered person in a public setting, but please be gentle with yourself. This is a "dry run" event. It's one of the first times we're hosting it. Expect some things to be bumpy or unrefined until we figure out the best format for this event. Feedback and suggestions are very welcome. 1 attendee 1 attendee

items.title: Conversation Cafe

It's one of the first times we're hosting it. Expect some things to be bumpy or unrefined until we figure out the best format for this event. Feedback and suggestions are very welcome. 1 attendee 1 attendee

items.title: Dry Run - Activity Buddies
items.description: Let's practice inviting people to join us at upcoming events and activities. Since the focus is on the activity and not exclusively each other, there is much less pressure or need to be vulnerable. We'll start by taking an inventory of what activities we do or would like to do that we could invite someone into. The focus will be on events we could go to alone or with a plus one, such as group classes or activity centered meetups in the next two weeks. Weather the person we're inviting is able to make it or has to cancel at the last minute, we should be able to have fun at these events with or without them. Every event you go to could have the potential to introduce you to more interesting people you could invite out. We will then practice weaving these events and activities into our conversations. If it happens to be a point of connection, it will be very easy to just invite them to join you next time. This is a "dry run" event. It's one of the first times we're hosting it. Expect some things to be bumpy or unrefined until we figure out the best format for this event. Feedback and suggestions are very welcome. 1 attendee 1 attendee

items.title: Initiating the Conversation
items.description: Let's practice starting low stakes conversations in low pressure environments. It's the gateway to more exciting and fulfilling social interactions in the future. Walking up to an intimidatingly beautiful or handsome stranger and trying to get them to like you is high pressure, high stakes. Talking to someone who looks friendly at a potluck, mixer or house party is low pressure. Our intention will set the stakes. To make it low stakes, our intention will be to simultaneously a) learn about the person we're talking to and b) share what we feel comfortable with about ourselves. It's not to get them to like us, sell them anything, or convince them of something we believe in. During the conversation you might find common interests, passions or activities. Or you might not. Either outcome is a win. Our goal is to learn to relax and maybe even feel playful while having these types of conversations. We'll discuss when it might be a good idea to exchange contact info and when doing so is more likely to leave you ghosted. This is a "dry run" event. It's one of the first times we're hosting it. Expect some things to be bumpy or unrefined until we figure out the best format for this event. Feedback and suggestions are very welcome. 1 attendee 1 attendee

items.title: Music Production Group Forming
items.description: Looking to bring people with at least a few years of experience in music production together to share tracks and feedback.There are currently 4 of us and I was going to write them about meeting in a week or two.If you would like to join, email me back with a link to your music.brokenoceanmusic@gmail.comI want to keep this small and for people who already put in several years of effort in learning this craft.At a minimum 3 years of experience and at least a 7 song EPs worth of released material is required.You don’t have to have done everything, but you should have done at least 2 of the following on your recordings: composition, engineering, mixing and mastering.Cheers,Eric

items.title: New Tech Seattle March 2024 - Creating Career & Business Advantages with GenAI
items.description: $20.00 *Please register for this event atti.to/new-tech-nw/new-tech-seattle-march-2024RSVPing on Meetup will not register you for this event. Join us on Thursday, March 14th from 5-7 pm for New Tech Seattle's next meet-up. New Tech is the Northwest's largest tech community. We're the place where you make meaningful connections, learn from the industry's best, and have a fun night out. Most importantly, you'll join an engaging group of go-getters, developers, founders, and professionals, and discover the people, partners, organizations, and resources to help you build your dreams. Enjoy hosted light appetizers, beverages, and a cash bar while you mingle with your peers. March PresenterTrent Gillespie, Fractional AI Officer, Founder & Chief Innovation Officer, Day One Innovation Move from guesswork to real results with generative AI by learning the framework-based prompting method created by former Amazon leader and AI and Innovation expert Trent Gillespie. Through the application of business frameworks, any employee can use generative AI to immediately increase the quality of their work, impressing their leadership and customers and simplifying their tasks. Trent will share this method and other insights from driving business adoption of generative AI. The CrowdThe Northwest’s smart, fun, creative, innovative tech community – software and application developers, company owners, startup founders, recruiters, hackers, job seekers, executives, investors, community leaders, and people who are new to the area. The FormatConnecting > community building > community shoutouts > sponsor shoutouts > panel discussion > afterparty The VibeNeighborhood block party – fun, friendly & relaxed with complimentary food & drinks. You’ll laugh, smile, and have a fun night out. The ExperienceDiscover innovative, creative and inspirational new technology (or smarter use of old tech). It could be VR, IoT, Apps, Fintech, Mobiletech, Healthtech, Cloudtech… you get the idea. Agenda5:00pm - Neighborhood block party style networking with appetizers, beverages & a cash bar6:00pm - Welcome! Time to start the show6:05pm - Sponsor Shoutouts6:10pm - Community Connections; quick shares with your neighbors6:15pm - Community Shoutouts; quick shares of cool events, resources & meet new Seattleites6:25pm - Presentation7:10pm - Thank you & goodnight, …or7:15pm - Afterparty in The Collective's High Tide community space The After PartyContinue connecting to fantastic people in our community after the show ends around 7:15 pm. The Tickets$20 before the event and $27 if purchased the day of the event. If you decide to park in the parking garage, the entrance is at the back of the building along a back alley. It's a one-way street, enter the alley from Harrison Street. By registering for a New Tech Northwest event, you agree to ourCode of ConductPolicy. RSVP NOW!

items.title: ADHD Oasis Meetup: Managing Rejection Sensitive Dysphoria [VIRTUAL]
items.description: Join us on Thursday March 21st, for New Tech’s ADHD Oasis Meetup: Managing Rejection Sensitive Dysphoria Register here.(Register through Meetup does not reserve your spot) March 21st Hot Topic – Managing Rejection Sensitive DysphoriaUnderstanding and managing rejection sensitive dysphoria (RSD) is really important, especially for adults with ADHD who might struggle with emotional regulation. RSD can cause intense pain in response to feeling rejected or criticized, and it’s tough because traditional therapies might not always help. People with RSD tend to have strong emotional reactions to negative feedback or feeling left out, and others might see them as being overly sensitive or perfectionistic. During this meetup we will talk about signs of RSD and ways to find personalized strategies that really make a difference in how it affects everyday life and happiness. Check out these articles before the meetup: You are not alone.Come join a community of peers where you can safely discuss yourneurodiverseexperiences with a supportive community of peers once month. You can attend these virtual Meetups on the third Thursday of every month. The more Meetups you attend, the more peer connections you’ll make with other professionals who have neurodiverse brains like you. Instead of being lonely in your experience, come laugh, learn, and connect with your community. Join us to be welcomed into a community that gets you and lives with similar neurodiverse brains. During the Meetups we’ll share struggles as well as systems and strategies to overcome your executive functioning and working memory challenges like anxiety, overwhelm, miscommunication, interrupting, inattentiveness, stress, distractibility, procrastination, paperwork fails, imposter syndrome, having to mask your neurodiversity at work, and weak organization skills. The CommunityProfessionals in technology who are managing ADHD, ADD, autism, dyslexia, depression, anxiety, or other neurodivergent conditions. The Agenda*You are welcome to show up late or leave early to suit your schedule. We understand that this is a workday event and unexpected priorities arise. We’re neurodiverse and understand these realities. The VibeSupportive community of neurodiverse folks who see, understand, and support the ups and downs of your neurodiverse journey. You’ll laugh, smile, and exhale the stresses around living in a neuerotypically-designed world and work places. Come share what you’re up to, be curious and helpful to others, and make some new friends in the tech community! The ExperienceReceive community support and professional coaching as you talk safely with fellow ADHDers and neurodiverse peers about your challenges and solutions around neurodiverse living & working as a professional. Get love, understanding, tools for support, and meet new friends in a fun and safe space. We have fun too. Attendee Requirements Our monthly virtual meetups are designed to foster collaboration and support within our ADHD tech community. Anyone working in tech who is seeking ADHD support is invited to join us. To ensure a focused environment, we kindly ask ADHD coaches not to join these events. ADHD Oasis meetups are not a place to coach group members or to actively seek clients. Thank you for your understanding. RSVP NOW!

items.title: Stammtisch
items.description: Come join us at Die Bierstube each Monday! Our favorite beer garden in the city has Munich Mondays where you can grab a liter and get $1.00 off. Also be sure to grab a membership punch card - the more punches, the more prizes! Be sure to give yourself a few extra minutes for parking. It’s not too difficult because it’s in a neighborhood rather than a city center but you still may need some time to find the right spot. As a friendly reminder, this group is a mix of language learners so people will be speaking at a variety of levels and there will be a mix of German and English being spoken. Many of us are new to, or rusty with, our vocabulary and grammar and may need to simply sit and listen, listen and speak, or speak English while listening and translating. This also is a social event as much as it is a language exchange so please be kind and patient with our members - we are all working on developing our language proficiency and hoping to make new friends while doing so. 🌸🍻

items.title: Let's play NEMESIS (+Carnomorphs) in First Hill!
items.location: The Rise on Madison, Seattle, WA
items.description: In space, no one can hear you scheme. Nemesiswill take you into the heart of sci-fi survival horror. A soldier fires blindly down a corridor, trying to slow the creatures' advance. A scientist races to find a solution in his makeshift lab. A traitor steals the only remaining escape pod at the very last moment. The hostile organisms infesting the ship are not only reacting to the noise you make, but also evolving as the time goes by. The longer the game takes, the stronger they become. This session will make use of theCarnomorphsexpansion, which replaces the usual lurking "Intruders" with a more aggressive, much hungrier kind of monster -- think lessAlienand moreDead Space. Ranked the #21 board game of all time on Board Game Geek -BGG info pageDeclared the "best horror game ever made" by No Rolls Barred Nemesisis a medium-high complexity semi-cooperative survival horror adventure game with an emphasis on exploration, resource management, and achieving individual goals that may or may not conflict with those of other players (including deliberately targeting those players for elimination from the game). New players are welcome, and the host is happy to teach if you haven't played before. 1 - 5 players3 - 4 hours expected play time, potentially longer depending on turnout and player familiarity A few important details:

items.title: Let's Play Cosmic Encounter!
items.location: The Rise on Madison, Seattle, WA
items.description: InCosmic Encounter, you are the leader of one of dozens of alien races, each with its own unique power. On your turn, you'll attempt to gain a colony in a random player's home system through force or negotiation. Each side will deploy forces, gather allies, secretly commit encounter cards, and then it's glory to the victor and woe to the loser, unless one side -- or both! -- plays special cards from their hands or uses their alien power to upset the victory or punish the winner. Players must use the right combination of force, cunning, and diplomacy to ensure victory. Alliances form and shift from moment to moment, so your nemesis can become your closest comrade with the flip of a card. And because alliances are a key part of the game, multiple players can win together. Will you go for a joint win? Or will you try to pull out a solo victory? On a personal note, I've probably played this game more than any other boardgame in my life. I've had some of my most fun moments around a gaming table with it. I will teach the game -- no experience needed. If you haven't played before, please try to show up a few minutes early for a quick introduction. The game is pretty easy to learn (rated 2.58/5.00 on boardgamegeek, where 3.00 is medium difficulty). Playtime varies based on the number of players, alien power combinations, and other factors, but we should be able to get in multiple rounds. I'll cancel if we don't get at least four people for the event, as Cosmic Encounter is not much fun at 3 players or less. For more information, including teaching videos, there are resources available on Boardgamegeek.com:Game info:https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/39463/cosmic-encounter Cosmic Encounter in about 3 minutes:https://boardgamegeek.com/video/378447/cosmic-encounter/cosmic-encounter-about-3-minutes...It outlines the basics of the rules but unfortunately doesn't really show the back-and-forth of the game. Attendees: the event will be held in the lounge space at an apartment complex. Watch your mail as the date approaches for contact information to get in! +1

items.title: Let's play THE QUEST FOR EL DORADO and MEXICA in First Hill!
items.location: The Rise on Madison, Seattle, WA
items.description: Both? Both is good! InThe Quest for El Dorado, players take the roles of expedition leaders who have embarked on a search for the legendary land of gold in the dense jungles of South America. Each player assembles and equips their own team, hiring various helpers from the scout to the scientist to the aborigine. All of them have one goal in mind: Reaching the golden border first and winning all of the riches for themselves. Whoever chooses the best tactics will be rewarded! The Quest for El Doradoon BoardGameGeek The Quest for El Doradois a medium-light complexity deckbuilding/racing hybrid game which also includes open drafting and a variable/modular board. New players are welcome, and the host is happy to teach if you haven't played before. 2 - 4 players30 - 60 minutes expected play time, depending on turnout and player familiarity And also.... Build the old Aztec city of Tenochtitlan with flowing canals and beautiful temples in a game of placement, blocking and majority.The third game in the "Mask Trilogy" collaboration between two of the most prolific designers in the industry, Michael Kiesling and Wolfgang Kramer,Mexicaplots the development of the city of Tenochtitlan on an island in Lake Texcoco. Players attempt to partition it into districts, place buildings, and construct canals. Mexicaon BoardGameGeek Mexicais a medium-complexity area majority/influence and abstract-strategy game with an emphasis on tile placement and city-building, and a high degree of player confrontation. New players are welcome, and the host is happy to teach if you haven't played before. 2 - 4 players90 - 120 minutes expected play time, depending on turnout and player familiarity A few important details:

items.title: Big Time Games at Big Time Brewery
items.location: Big Time Brewing Company, Seattle, WA
items.description: Come to Big Time Brewery in the U District to play some big time games! All games are welcome, but we will be bringing and trying to play more strategic/heavier games and fewer party games/activities. Not that we're opposed! Feel free to bring anything you'd like. We're happy to teach and/or play most games. don't be dissuaded if the RSVPs are low. There is a solid group that shows every week and doesn't RSVP on Meetup. Big Time Brewery has lots of space. We will be in the back with a pile of games, unless posted otherwise. Hope to get games going by 2:30, but you may find other stragglers or we may start with something short if you're late. This is a safe, fun, competitive, and welcoming environment for all! Hope to see you there

items.title: Board Game Night @ Die Bierstube!
items.description: Board game night @ Die Bierstube in the Roosevelt neighborhood! All experience levels and interests are welcome; we'll be more than happy to teach you how to play! Drop in any time and we'll get you into a game ASAP. I'll be bringing games from my collection, but feel free to bring any games you'd like to share with the group! We tend to get a very wide variety of games played at the event so don't be shy about bringing out your favorites. Please support the bar while you play so we can keep this amazing location! Die Bierstube has a great selection of German beers on tap, cocktails and wine, snacks and small plates, soups and salads, sandwiches and other entrees. We have a great location and friendly service and we want to make sure we are supporting them so we can continue using this great location! Please note that attendance is capped at 12 people for this event. This is due to limited space being available at the bar. Please only RSVP if you are certain you will be attending. If your plans change, please cancel your RSVP as soon as possible so someone on the waitlist can get a spot. Thank you. +7

items.title: Board Game Night @ Teddy's Tavern!
items.description: Tabletop game night at Teddy's Tavern in the Roosevelt neighborhood! I'll be bringing a selection of games from my collection. Feel free to bring any games you might want to share.

items.title: Power Cube (Magic the Gathering) at Rhein Haus
items.description: Please don’t rsvp unless you plan to attend the event. There are limited spaces and I would like to have them available for those interested in attending. The Cube: https://cubecobra.com/cube/list/jacksun For those who aren't familiar with Cube drafting. It's just like any other booster draft but, the 3 booster packs of 15 cards will come from a curated list of proxied cards (posted above). We will play 3 rounds of best of 3 games. The winner of the night (3-0) gets to sign a basic land in the cube. If you’re interested in learning more about drafting Power Cube this is a great resource: https://open.spotify.com/episode/22TjR4aHuZDxOUEBvk6hok... (starts around 16:35) There's no need to bring anything, just a way to keep track of life totals. This is a casual event, please don’t be a rules lawyer, we’re here to have fun. Feel Free to invite others, we draft every Tuesday. This event will be canceled if we don’t have 6 drafters. Join us on discord! https://discord.gg/nTF5ddW33S 1 attendee 1 attendee

items.title: Let's play ORLÉANS in First Hill!
items.location: The Rise on Madison, Seattle, WA
items.description: During the medieval goings-on around the city of Orléans, you must assemble a following of farmers, merchants, knights, monks, and others to gain supremacy through trade, construction and science in medieval France. InOrléans, you will recruit followers and put them to work to make use of their abilities. Farmers and Boatmen supply you with money and goods; Knights expand your scope of action and secure your mercantile expeditions; Craftsmen build trading stations and tools to facilitate work; Scholars make progress in science; Traders open up new locations for you to use your followers; and last but not least, it cannot hurt to get active in monasteries since with Monks on your side you are much less likely to fall prey to fate. You will always want to take more actions if possible, and there are many paths to victory. The challenge is to combine all elements as best as possible with regard to your strategy. Ranked the #31 game of all time on Board Game Geek!2017 Nederlandse Spellenprijs Best Expert Game Winner2017 MinD-Spielepreis Complex Game Winner2016 Gouden Ludo Best Expert Game Winner2015 JUG Adult Game of the Year Winner Orléans(pronounced "awr-ley-AHN")is a medium-complexity worker placement/bag-building hybrid game which also includes resource collection and point-to-point movement. New players are welcome, and the host is happy to teach if you haven't played before. 2 - 5 players90 - 120 minutes expected play time, depending on turnout and player familiarity How It's Playedwith Rodney Smith(Don't worry, we'll go over the rules on the night too!) A few important details:

items.title: Let's Play INIS in First Hill!
items.location: The Rise on Madison, Seattle, WA
items.description: Inisis a game deeply rooted in Celtic history and lore in which players win by being elected King of the Island (Inis). Players can achieve victory through three different conditions: Leadership, Land, or Religion. While meeting a single condition may sometimes be enough to claim the crown, often a tight balance of power will require a player to meet several conditions at once. Careful drafting, hand management, bluffing, good timing, and a precise understanding of the balance of power are the keys to victory. A BoardGameGeek.com top 100 game!Shut Up and Sit Down Recommends Inis(pronounced "inn-ish") is a medium-complexity area majority/influence and hand management game which also includes card drafting, politics/negotiation, exploration, and some combat. New players are welcome, and the host is happy to teach if you haven't played before. 2 - 5 players90 - 120 minutes expected play time, depending on turnout and player familiarity How to Play(Don't worry, we'll go over the rules on the night, too.) A few important details:

items.title: [In-Person][T1][S9] D&D Adventurer's League This Thursday!
items.location: Stoup Brewing - Capitol Hill, Seattle, WA
items.description: Adventurer’s League is back in Seattle! Join us at Stoup Capitol Hill this Thursday as we jump into the Forgotten Realms for new adventures every week. Just The Facts: Play Start Time: 6:00pm (We are always open to helping new players. Show up a few minutes before play if you need help creating a character) Tier: 1, Level 1-4 Module Details: DDAL09-03, Hungry Shadows: Bodies continue pile up, and the Flaming Fist still has nothing but a name. Thankfully, the perpetrator of the murders has slipped up and the Flaming Fist has captured one of their underlings, in turn, has revealed the presence of a cult hideout in the sewers beneath the city. The Flaming Fist has asked that you investigate. Are you up for the task?Part Two of the Betrayal is in the Blood series of adventures. The Basics: The D&D Adventurers League is an ongoing official campaign for Dungeons & Dragons. It uses the fifth edition Dungeons & Dragons rules and features the Forgotten Realms setting. You can play D&D Adventurers League games literally anywhere. Players use the fifth edition rules to create a character and bring that character to games anywhere D&D Adventurers League play is happening. Each module is a separate adventure. So no need to have played with the group before. What You Need: A character, level 1-4 At least three hours to complete an adventure. How is this different from any other D&D game I’ve played? AL is tracked by you. Your character can jump into any AL game anywhere in the world as long as you track your progress. Any levels, gold, or loot that you receive can be carried over to another game with a completely different Dungeon Master and players. If you want to learn more about DDAL, please see the below resources from Wizards of the Coast. I recommend you read through the DDAL Player’s Guide if you want to know more details about how the league operates. Wizards of the Coast Official Adventurer's League Page https://dnd.wizards.com/ddal_general Players Guide https://media.wizards.com/2021/dnd/downloads/DDAL_PlayersGuidev11_0.pdf DDAL Forgotten Realms FAQ https://media.wizards.com/2021/dnd/downloads/DDAL_Forgotten_Realms_FAQ_v11.1.pdf Interested in tracking your adventures online? Adventurer's League Log is the most lightweight and free resource so you don't have to carry the paper log sheet around. https://www.adventurersleaguelog.com/ +2

items.title: Virtual Book Club - The Book of Three by Lloyd Alexander
items.description: Event Type: Book ClubBook: The Book of Three by Lloyd AlexanderPlatform: Zoom ******** First published in March 12, 1964, we celebrate the 60th anniversary of it's publication!The Book of Three (1964) is a high fantasy novel, by American writer Lloyd Alexander, the first of five volumes in The Chronicles of Prydain. The series follows the adventures of Taran the Assistant Pig-Keeper, a youth raised by Dallben the enchanter, as he nears manhood while helping to resist the forces of Arawn Death-Lord. Inspired by Welsh mythology, The Book of Three has been a long favorite children's novel. The Book of Three and its successor, The Black Cauldron, were loosely adapted by Walt Disney Productions and released in 1985 as Disney's 25th animated feature film, under the latter title. (Not recommended by this Event Host.) I'll leave it open to have discussions about the whole Chronicles of Prydain series. The Chronicles of Prydain is a pentalogy of children's high fantasy Bildungsroman novels. The series includes: The Book of Three (1964), The Black Cauldron (1965), The Castle of Llyr (1966), Taran Wanderer (1967), and The High King (1968). The Black Cauldron earned a 1966 Newbery Honor, and The High King won the 1969 Newbery Medal. ******** From the earliest days, tabletop roleplaying games have been designed to empower players to create and interact with stories modeled after literary fiction. Look at Appendix N from the Dungeon Master's Guide (p. 244, E. G. Gygax 1979), A Cyberpunk Bibliography from Cyberpunk 2020 (p. 187, M. Pondsmith 1990), Hiding Your Sources from Vampire: the Masquerade (p. 258, M. Rein-Hagen 1991), or the list you'll probably find towards the back of your favorite RPG. This month we're reading The Book of Three by Lloyd Alexander. Feel free to read the entire series. In my opinion, in the early days of D&D, high fantasy book series were few (not counting pulp series by authors like Burroughs or Howard), and I put JRR Tolkien, Lloyd Alexander, and CS Lewis as the foundations of the genre. Come join us to talk about the plot, characters, and themes of the book, or maybe what aspects of it you would want to borrow for your games! I hope to see you there! My events are a positive, friendly, and welcoming spaces for all readers, regardless of class, race, gender, age, or sexual identity. Any negativity fueled by real-world ignorance, hate, or fear will be met with swift action and possible permanent banishment to Dante's Nine Circles. Please keep your RSVP up to date!! If you change your plans, update your RSVP!! Having everyone No Show an event is frustrating. Any other questions? Just ask! +3

items.title: Dont miss out ! Backpacking to Havasupai!
items.description: Join us for a heart-pumping trip filled with fun and friendship for a backpacking trip to Havasupai wonderland!Embark on an unforgettable journey into the heart of the Grand Canyon as we invite you to join us for the ultimate Havasupai backpacking experience! Immerse yourself in the breathtaking beauty of Havasu Falls, where turquoise waters cascade into pristine pools against the rugged backdrop of the canyon walls.We have 1 mule reserved for the group, in case if you need help carrying backpack.Adding all to waitlist first here. Join whatsapp group for entry to the event. DM me for any questions. -https://chat.whatsapp.com/Fqwhso1HjPnKaEHuLQi2in🏞Event Highlights:1. Scenic Trails:Traverse through the iconic Havasu Canyon, navigating trails that wind through stunning landscapes and showcase the region's unique geological features.2. Havasu Falls:Witness the awe-inspiring Havasu Falls, a natural wonder that captivates with its vibrant blue-green hues. Marvel at the powerful cascades and enjoy moments of tranquility in this surreal oasis.3. Camp by the Waters:Set up camp beside the crystal-clear waters of Havasu Creek. Fall asleep to the soothing sounds of nature and wake up to the sun casting its warm glow on the canyon walls.4. Mooney Falls:Challenge your adventurous spirit as you descend the thrilling cliffside ladders to reach Mooney Falls, another gem in the Havasu Canyon crown. The reward? A breathtaking view and a sense of accomplishment.5. Navajo Falls:Delight in the charm of Navajo Falls, a hidden gem that adds an extra touch of magic to this already enchanting journey.6. Stargazing:As night falls, be captivated by the vast, unpolluted sky, offering a celestial display like no other. Stargazing in the Grand Canyon is a mesmerizing experience, providing the perfect backdrop for storytelling and camaraderie.7. Community Bonfire:Gather around a communal bonfire, sharing stories and forging connections with fellow adventurers. Experience the true spirit of camaraderie as you create lasting memories under the stars.⛺️Logistics: Join us for an expedition into the heart of Havasupai, where every step is a brushstroke on the canvas of a once-in-a-lifetime adventure. Reserve your spot now and make memories that will last a lifetime! 1 attendee 1 attendee

items.title: Enchantments Backpacking Hike [LONG and HARD]
items.location: Green Lake Park & Ride, Seattle, WA
items.description: IntroductionThe enchantments is a captivating paradise in WA that everyone should visit once. Nature has carved one of the magnificent places of this world--an alpine paradise of granite worn smooth by glaciers, larches manicured by wind and cold, and crystal blue lakes strung together by a creek that tumbles and thunders between them. Seemingly everywhere, herds of mountain goats calmly wander by. Superlatives simply don’t suffice, and you quickly find yourself resorting to otherworldly comparisons, just like the early visitors who bestowed place names like Aasgard, Sprite and Leprechaun on the fairytale surroundings. Since this is early May, we won't need a permit for the core zone of enchantments. I plan for us to travel to core zone on the 1st day and camp there. 2nd day we will get up early, pack up everything and hike all the way to snowlake. Passes Needed ScheduleMy current plan is to meet at Green Lake Park & Ride early to drive out. If you want to meet at Trailhead we can arrange that but I might ask you to arrange to pick a rider to bring with you. We will all start at hiking at Stuart/Colchuck Lake Trailhead and setup camp at Core Zone the first night. Then 2nd day wake up early around 7am, pack up by 8am, and hike to the Snowlake Trailhead. This means we will need to all drive to Snowlake Trailhead and park 2 of our cars at Snowlake Trailhead. The 2 cars will carry all 8 of us to from Snowlake Trailhead parking to Stuart/Colchuck Lake Trailhead. When we finish at Snowlake Trail then we can take the 2 cars we parked there and drive them to Stuart/Colchuck Lake Trailhead to pick up the 2 cars we have there. Then we drive back home. This means we need at least 4 drivers and preferably 6 for backup. This means 6 out of the 8 people who will be allowed will be drivers. I intentionally built in lots of extra time by starting early to make it safer for everyone so we can do it before it gets dark. It also allows us time to take pictures. This schedule gives us lots of backup time but likely we will be able to go faster than what is shown below. My hope is we can be faster on the first day so we can check out Horseshoe Lake. Required Equipment: 1 attendee 1 attendee

Dropouts June 5th and after will have no refunds on camping or airbnb or attendance deposit unless trip is cancelled or there is a waitlist and a suitable replacement. items.title: Yellowstone Trip over Labor Day week
items.location: Green Lake Park & Ride, Seattle, WA
items.description: Discover Yellowstone's Marvels:Embark on an extraordinary expedition into Yellowstone, where geysers, majestic wildlife, and stunning landscapes converge. This adventure invites you to explore the iconic beauty of the world's first national park, a realm where geysers erupt, bison roam freely, and canyons carve through the Earth.As you traverse the ecosystems of Yellowstone, you'll marvel at the power of Old Faithful, and encounter elusive grizzly bears, bighorn sheep, and herds of majestic bison.Our campground and lodges booked are in the heart of Yellowstone making them accessible to all locations.If you are not comfortable with hiking or encountering bears, you can skip those activities but still come with us.Tours<- Click for more infoItinerary:The detailed itinerary will only be shared to those who are confirmed.We will hit all 17 of the top visiting spots inUS News Report for Yellowstone. This is possible because we have booked the most ideal location for camping and lodging.August 30: Travel to Yellowstone August 31-1: Grand Canyon at Yellowstone September 2-5: Yellowstone's Geysers and grizzly bear and wolf visitor center September 6-7: Northern Yellowstone and visit bison and bear and wolf sightings location September 8: Departure Equipment: Check the linkCost:Check this link for more infohttps://docs.google.com/document/d/18BSs-4VQU-Y57Jjp_5JiNIySnckzDF_P0bb59W_lRv4/edit?usp=sharingAccommodation Availability: Refund Policy: WaitlistThe waitlist is ordered so those who get on waitlist first have priority over later joiners. Paying the full amount secures you a spot on the waitlist if the event is full. If a spot opens up then I will reach out and ask if you're interested in joining. If you are interested then you can join us and if not then I'll refund. Anyone who doesn't get off waitlist by the start will be refunded.Payment methods:Make sure payment is for friends/family Liability Waiver:Filling this out is requiredhttps://forms.gle/qixLSoLoC8NYMNvw9***Communication: Google docs linkfor more info 1 attendee 1 attendee

items.title: Wednesday Night Run @ the Trailhead!
items.description: Join us at the Wednesday Night Run @ the Trailhead! Each week, we follow one of our scenic (and usually hilly) 4-mile routes. To see where we're running this week, see our route map & schedulehere. We run year-round, in rain or shine, and despite what you see in the RSVP list, we've been averaging ~60 runners a week. First-timers are always welcome, as are any out-of-town visitors looking for a fun group of runners! We try to make sure that everyone arrives safely back to port: many of us know all of the routes, we have laminated mini route maps available at the start, and we usually have sweepers running near the back. Pace-wise, the group typically ranges from 7:30 to 10:30 minutes per mile. Most of our routes have a photo stop, usually about halfway, where everyone regroups. If you're looking for something a little shorter or longer, or something stroller-friendly, just ask us for some shortcut, add-on, or detour suggestions. On-leash dogs are also welcome. Questions? Just ask! We want your first Wednesday Night Run to be a success! We start meeting up at 5:20pm at the Brooks Trailhead store at 3400 Stone Way in Seattle's Fremont neighborhood (depending on the weather, we may be inside the store). At 5:35pm, we have introductions, describe the route, and take off. We finish back at the store. Afterward, most of us head across the street toFremont Brewing, where we hang out and socialize (it's kid and dog friendly). They have tasty craft beer and cider on tap, as well as some non-alcoholic choices (they have very limited food options, however). They have indoor and covered outdoor seating (heaters when it's cold, misters when it's hot). If you can't make the 5:30pm run (timing, rest day, injury, whatever), you are definitely welcome to meet us at the brewery. We're usually there by 6:30pm; just look for the runners! If you need to use the restroom or lockers to store your stuff during the run, the Brooks Trailhead store has both inside. Keep in mind that the store closes at 7pm. The Wednesday Night Run is also on Strava! Connect with usthere, too! =================== If you're new to the Seattle Green Lake Running Group (SGLRG), the Wednesday Night Run is just one of our many regular weekly runs. Monday Morning Track (5:30am)Monday Evening Track (6:30pm)Tuesday Evening Run (6:30pm)Wake Up Wednesday (5:30am)Wednesday Night Run (5:30pm)Thursday Evening Casual Run (6:30pm)Friday Lake Union Run (6:00am)Saturday Morning Rise & Shine (7:00am)Saturday Mid-Morning Run (9:00am)Sunday Stair Climbing Workout (10:00am, every other week)Sunday Trail Run (9:00 or 10:00am, twice a month)Sunday Morning Bakery Run (9:00 or 10:00am, monthly) See the entire SGLRGevent calendar. SGLRG also has anactive community group on Facebook, where you can discuss all things running and find running buddies. +9

items.title: Thursday Evening Casual Run
items.location: Road Runner Sports - Green Lake, Seattle, WA
items.description: Thursday Evening Casual Run is a social run welcoming runners of all levels. We meet at Road Runner Sports (Green Lake location, 7020 Woodlawn Ave NE) at 6:30, run to Green Lake, and turn left. After the run, we eat! During the warmer months we disperse to grab takeout (PCC, Local Bigger Burger, Zeeks, and Frelard Tamales are all good options nearby!) and meet back at the lake to eat together. Bring a blanket/towel! There are 3, 4, and 5 mile routes with runners at a variety of paces. We generally stick to the outer loop on Green Lake which is a little more runner-friendly, but recommend the inner loop for the section along Aurora due to heavy traffic. Don't hesitate to ask for a regular to run with you if you want help following the route. 3 Mile Route:https://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/view/4472596675 4 Mile Route:https://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/view/4474850398 5 Mile Route:https://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/view/4474855288 +2

items.title: Friday Lake Union Run!
items.description: We'll be meeting at our usual spot on 34th Street across from the "Waiting for the Interurban" statue. We run the Lake Union loop counter-clockwise. Those with time will gather for coffee afterwards at (currently outside) Milstead & Co. HEALTH AND SAFETY: Please DO NOT ATTEND this week if you are unwell or have had recent contact with anyone who might be covid positive. MASKS/BUFFS/FACE-COVERINGS: Please wear or bring one at least for the start. Once we are running each small group can decide on their own policy, but please be respectful to anyone who chooses to wear a face covering.

items.title: Lake Sammamish Half Marathon
items.description: Hello!Are you participating in this yearsLake Sammamish Half Marathon? Please RSVP if you are so we can see who will be running from the group. This is definitely been one of the most popular events this group participates in over the years and it is always a lot of run to cheer each other on throughout the course. We always meet up for a group photo before the race, so if you would like to join, we will be at theDowntown Park6:40am. The Seattle Green Lake Running Group is the official pacers for the race and will have pacers for 1:30, 1:40, 1:50, 2:00, 2:15 and 2:30. If that matches what you have planned, you should run with the pacers and enjoy some group effort to help you reach your goal! For more information on the event, please take a look at theLSH event details. +32

items.title: Lake Sammamish Half Marathon Training!
items.description: Hello Everyone! Do you need something to keep you running through the winter? The Lake Sammamish Half has served as a great event for the group to target as one of those first races of the year. Especially after a long winter this race usually provides many personal bests for lots of our runners! We will be sharing weekly running schedule for the week on Sunday's and you are welcome to follow it exactly or modify it based on where you are with your running and to make sure you get what you need out of it. We will have a suggested beginner plan and intermediate plan and hopefully this can be a great opportunity for you to team up with other runners at our weekly runs to share the workouts with. These build ups can be a great way to make new friends, improve your consistency and survive winter by being active. Please join us if you are interested! +8

items.title: Saturday Morning Rise & Shine Run!
items.location: Green Lake Small Craft Center /aka "boathouse", Seattle, WA
items.description: Every Saturday morning we have a nice tradition of getting together and starting our day with a group run. Each week participants RSVP, post their goal distance and pace in the comments Come find us at 7am every Saturday morning as we organize into distance and pace groups and review the route they are running each week. Find new training partners, meet new friends, and enjoy the benefits of running with others. Our weekly running routes and plan will be posted below each week, please review the route maps prior to the start of the run. Posting in the comments and arriving on time each will increase your chances of finding others to run. Thanks for running with us! This event is only as successful as those who show up to support it! ——————- Saturday Morning Rise & Shine Routes- +8

items.title: Saturday Mid-Morning Run
items.description: ~We'll be in the Seattle Public Theater parking lot What Three Words app = wicked.hops.urban~ Routes for this week over 3 miles will take us to John Lewis Memorial Bridge 3 mile - https://www.mapmyfitness.com/routes/view/4444515358 5 mile - https://www.mapmyfitness.com/routes/view/4728200962 6 mile - https://www.mapmyfitness.com/routes/view/4728208780 8 mile - https://www.mapmyfitness.com/routes/view/4728230683 The Saturday Mid-Morning Run welcomes runners/walkers of all abilities paces and distances. We have a rotation of routes that range anywhere from 3 to 12 miles long. By RSVP'ing and commenting in this meetup event lets others know what pace and distance you are looking to run/walk and the more comments and RSVP's means more people will be willing to venture out knowing that someone will be running/walking at their same pace and distance -- comments help! What is What Three Words? https://support.what3words.com/en/articles/2212807-how-do-what3words-addresses-work =================== Saturday Mid-Morning Run route rotation and upcoming dates: Golden Gardens/Sunset Hill Park — 2/17Phinney Ridge neighborhood — 2/24Ravenna Park — 3/2John Lewis Memorial Bridge — 3/9Visit the Troll — 3/16 UW Quad — Cherry Blossoms Run ? TBDKeep an eye on the campus webcams to see when the trees will reach their peak.https://www.washington.edu/video/campus-webcams/ If you want to suggest a route or make a comment about a route, feel free to drop me a PM. If you're new to the Seattle Green Lake Running Group (SGLRG), the Saturday Mid-Morining Run is just one of our many regular weekly runs. See the SGLRG calendar of runs here: https://www.meetup.com/Seattle-Greenlake-Running-Group/events/calendar/ === While we’re excited to have you join us once again, we do have some new guidelines for all participants of SGLRG to keep everyone safe and healthy. The most up to date information about COVID protocols for the SGLRG can be found at this link -- https://safety.rungreenlake.com/ Expectations for this group run: * Please do not attend if you are experiencing any COVID-19 related symptoms, had exposure to anyone with COVID-19, or have had COVID-19 yourself in the past 3 weeks. * As of 02/17/22, masks are no longer required for this event. Please be considerate of your fellow runners' personal comfort level with their choices * Our goal is to not bombard pathways, trails, sidewalks and streets, so please follow traffic laws at all times and be aware of those around you on foot, bicycles and automobiles. Staying to the right will allow room for others to pass uninhibited on the left. when passing others please consider going single file in order to allow for greater spacing as you pass. * During our events, please keep in mind that we are all coming from different places and this pandemic has impacted all of us in different ways. Be respectful with your language and conversational topics. Running is a safe topic and a good building block to get to know others better. We want our events to be a safe place in which our members don’t feel threatened, harassed, or experiencing unwelcomed advances. Running is a great way to get to know other and it has helped us build a great community within the Seattle Green Lake Running Group. We can all make a big difference in each other’s overall experience and whether members want to continue attending events. * If at any point you have questions/concerns regarding the group, our events, upcoming trainings, races, ideas, incidents, etc...please reach out to our event hosts or group organizers. Thank you for being a part of the Seattle Green Lake Running Group! +7

items.title: Stair Climbing Workout
items.location: 10th Ave E & E Howe St, Seattle, WA
items.description: The name of the event says it all, we climb stairs for a great lower body exercise. This event comes around every Sunday and it is for all fitness levels. We start with a warm-up drill where we climb for about 4-5 minutes using different leg variations to get blood flowing. Then we go freestyle for about 30-45 mins. Freestyle here means running up the stairs, walking, jogging, crawling, squad-jumping, frog-jumping,.... however you want to do it as long as you're climbing up the stairs. You'll probably get sore afterwards if you haven't done a stair workout before or it has been a while since you did one but don't let that stop you. Your body will adapt pretty fast if you do it consistently. Strong, powerful, legs/lower-body, burn serious calories, get your heart-rate up-- all in 30-45 mins From the bottom(Lakeview Boulevard) to the top(10th Ave E), there are 13 flights of stairs that gives you a total of 282 steps. This event happens twice a month: 2nd and 4th Sunday of the month. Google maps link to the stairs: https://goo.gl/maps/ixoHvLFrAZVwiHit6 +5

items.title: Monday Morning On Track!
items.location: Roosevelt High School Track, Seattle, WA
items.description: We normally recommend a different workout each week for the group. Please check the comments here a few days before the event for details of the week's group workout. NOTE: During marathon training seasons (often spring and late-summer) those training for marathon sometimes run longer repeats off the track (often, but not always, running over to Green Lake to run them on the "inner loop" path). HEALTH AND SAFETY: Please DO NOT ATTEND this week if you are unwell or have had recent contact with anyone who might be covid positive. MASKS/BUFFS/FACE-COVERINGS: We are no longer requiring face coverings at the start but please be respectful to anyone who chooses to wear a face covering at any time.

items.title: Monday Evening Track (MET)
items.location: Lower Woodland (Park Playfields) Track, Seattle, WA
items.description: Welcome to Monday Evening Track (MET)Do you need a change of pace? Want to improve your running speed? Missing that final kick during a race? Just want a great workout? MET is for you!! The goal is to give runners the tools and a safe and friendly environment that enables them pursue the running speed of their dream.** Workouts are provided and explained by the event host.** If the workout is too much for where you are, we are always happy to customize it for you.** You can run a completely different workout and just join us for company and accountability!** Runners of all speeds, levels and abilities are encouraged to join. Newbies need not worry as they'll benefit from a great explanation of workouts. Typically this is how we roll starting at 6:30pm: Optional: The track is dirk track in Lower Woodland Park. To find us, google "Lower Woodland - Soccer Field #7". The track is around this soccer field. We usually hangout by the bleachers/benches on the north side of the soccer field for a few minutes before we get started. A good running pace/time/distance calculator:https://runsmartproject.com/calculator/ Please don't forget to join us at PCC in Greenlake for dinner after the workout

items.title: Seattle Hardware Happy Hour March 2024!
items.location: Fremont Brewing's Urban Beer Garden, Seattle, WA
items.description: Hardware Happy Hour (3H) Seattle will be holding our March meetup at Fremont Brewing. We will be meeting on January 4th 7-9pm PST. FYI - The brewery closes promptly at 9pm and last call is usually 8:30. We will be meeting in the outside beer garden. We do not have a reserved table (since they do not take reservations) but there should be plenty of space. Fremont Brewing does have some limited food options and there are a few local restaurants that do take out (The Dock Sports Bar next door has great burgers and wings). https://www.fremontbrewing.com/food Directions/Parking/Transportation: What We'll Do: Maker Exchange Box:If you have something to share/donate to the local maker community... microcontrollers, breadboards, motors, resistors, LEDs, filament... give those projects you abandoned a new life! Important to know:Please read the Contributor Covenant: https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/1/4/code-of-conduct.html Communication/Question:If you have any questions or need some more information on this event, please post them to the Seattle channel of the 3H Discord server. 3H Discord:https://discord.gg/Zp2xf3R +10

items.title: Seattle Hardware Happy Hour (3H) April 2024!
items.description: Seattle Hardware Happy Hour (3H) will be at PostDoc Brewing for our April 2024 event. What We'll Do:• Have fun!• Share projects and stories. Maker Exchange Box:If you have something to share/donate to the local maker community... microcontrollers, breadboards, motors, resistors, LEDs, filament... give those projects you abandoned a new life! Parking:There is typically plenty of parking between the parking lot right in front of PostDoc Brewing or street parking of 65th street. Food:Food truck has not been announced but check back closer to the event for an update. Request:PostDoc Brewing has generously reserves a few tables for our group at no charge. They have been a great partner in our ability to host events over the last few years. Buying beer and/or supporting the food truck is the best way to show your appreciating for them supporting this community. And buying beer to-go (instead of drinking during the event) is another great way to support PostDoc. Important to Know:Please read the Contributor Covenant: https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/1/4/code-of-conduct.html Communication/Question:If you have an questions or need some more information on this event please post them to the Seattle channel of the 3H Discord server.3H Discord: https://discord.gg/Zp2xf3R 1 attendee 1 attendee

items.location: Capitol Hill Comedy / Bar, Seattle, WA
items.description: $20.00 # Flock! Presents: Funny Queer Asians Featuring some of the best comedians in the PNW, one of Seattle's favorite queer comedy shows returns for a special evening of live, queer, and uniquely Asian standup comedy. Funny Queer Asians is a celebration of intersectionality across the queer and Asian-American communities! 1 attendee 1 attendee

items.title: Indie Co-working Support Group (ISG - IRL)
items.location: Academy of Interactive Entertainment, Seattle, WA
items.description: Curious how to start learning something? Want to chat with someone of another discipline? Need a place to work on a project and share it with others? ISG is a social, game development focused work group that encourages people of all skill levels and disciplines to come together and collaborate for the benefit of all. This is a great place to begin your game development journey and learn from fellow game creators as they work on their projects. To attend, you must be fully vaccinated (second shot received by October 5th). Note that you will need to bring proof of vaccination (a photo on your phone is okay) and identification. Bring your laptopand any software you will need to work on your game/art/music. How it Works: • Show up, introduce yourself, let everyone know what you hope to accomplish • Ask for help with anything, get to know others, share your projects, or enjoy the company of others as you work! • Share your highs and lows, high fives all around *** How to find us:It can be kind of hard to find us! We are on the 4th floor of the Armory building. Follow the signs to the restrooms, and nearby you'll find the stairs and the elevator. Take one of those to the fourth floor and look for the Seattle Indies banner. *** Accessibility information:There is paid street parking all around the neighborhood. There are paid parking garages at 516 Harrison St, 650 3rd Ave N, and at the corner of 5th Ave N and Harrison St. The Seattle Center has nearby bus stops serviced by the 1, 2, 3, 4, 8, 13, 15, 17, 18, 19, 24, 32, 33, D Line, and the monorail. The venue is listed as wheelchair accessible. The Seattle Center has additional accessibility information available on their website here: http://www.seattlecenter.com/about/accessibility.aspx If you are coming by Light Rail it is best to get off at Westlake Station and then ride the Monorail over to the Seattle Center which drops you off right at the Armory. *** Seattle Indies strives to be an inclusive and welcoming community for everyone. By attending our events, you are agreeing to follow our code of conduct (https://www.seattleindies.org/code-of-conduct/).

items.title: Seattle Indies Social
items.description: Join us in Capitol Hill for some well-deserved mingling, drinks, and socialization! Make some new friends, catch up with old ones, and find out what the community's up to. NOTE: This month we are running the event a week earlier than usual to avoid conflicting with GDC. *** Accessibility information:The venue is listed as wheelchair accessible. It is right next to bus stops serviced by the 2, 9, 43, 49, 60. Most nearby street parking areas are paid, and there are a few paid garage parking options nearby (Seattle Central Garage is often $5 or $10). There is one big unisex bathroom for everyone, with individual stalls for urinals and toilets. *** Seattle Indies is an inclusive and welcoming community for everyone. By attending our events, you are agreeing to follow our code of conduct (https://www.seattleindies.org/code-of-conduct/). +11

items.title: Northside Social
items.description: It's time to get together and swap stories. Put down your keyboards and brave the outdoors. Let's meet for a coffee/tea, a bite to eat, and some good conversation! *** This event is wheelchair accessible. The entrance, at street level, is located on the corner of Roosevelt Way NE and NE 64th St. We will most likely meet in the side room which can be accessed via a ramp. *** Seattle Indies strives to be an inclusive and welcoming community for everyone. By attending our events, you are agreeing to follow our code of conduct (https://www.seattleindies.org/code-of-conduct/). +1

items.title: Pre-GDC Indie Game Developer Park Meetup 2024
items.description: Calling all independent game developers at GDC 2024! Let’s catch up with old friends and make new ones at Dolores Park the afternoon before GDC. Location: Dolores Park (NOT Yerba Buena!)19th & Dolores St, San Francisco, CA 94114Let's meet at the bottom of the hill, just south of the Mexico Liberty Bell.GPS: 37.7596230367233, -122.42624601196376 How to get there:- Go to Powell Station from Moscone Center (2 blocks)- Take the J MUNI to Church & 18th- You can also take BART to 16th and Mission and walk a few blocks to the park- If you don't want to deal with SF public transit you can always get a Lyft Some notes:- You probably want to wear a sweater or light jacket (especially as the sun sets)- Feel free to bring your own food and drinks (none will be provided). Check Google or Yelp for a lot of great take-out restaurants close by- There are public restrooms on the north side of the park- Clean up after yourself. Don’t litter!- Drinking alcohol in public parks is illegal in San Francisco +401

items.title: Game Club
items.description: What a book club is to discussion of literature, this event is to discussion of game design. Every month, we agree to play a game, then meet to discuss and analyze its design and presentation. To participate: Check the #game-club channel for this month's game and join the Game Club Voice channel to join the discussion. We'll discuss our individual impressions and insights, and hopefully come away better and wiser game creators. --- Seattle Indies strives to be an inclusive and welcoming community for everyone. By attending our events, you are agreeing to follow our code of conduct (https://www.seattleindies.org/code-of-conduct/).

items.title: Monthly Show and Tell
items.description: Bring your laptop and show off what you're working on at the Seattle Indies Demo Night. Use this event to get feedback on your game and to network with other game devs. Pizza will be provided. Please bring everything you will need to demo and record feedback for your game. Pen and paper games are welcome alongside digital ones. Projects at all stages of development are welcome. This event is recurring every month on the first tuesday of the month. This event will be at spaces belltown. Enter the building and walk down the hallway to find the open door.

items.title: Seattle JS Monthly Meetup
items.description: ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Note: you MUST purchase a ticket 🎟 to attend →https://ti.to/event-loop/---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- It's the 2nd Wednesday of the month, time to hang out with your fellow web developers at The Collective Seattle! 5:30pm: Doors Open 🚪6:30pm: Kick-off and announcements 📣6:35pm: A word from our sponsors 🍕6:40pm: Talks, Networking & Socializing 🍻8:30pm: Farewell 👋 More info on speakers and talks →https://seattlejs.com +16

items.title: Code Katas with Seattle JS Hackers
items.location: AWS Skills Center Seattle, Seattle, WA
items.description: Welcome to Code Katas with Seattle JS Hackers This event will be held in-person, participants will also need to join our Discord to post solutions and get links to Katas.Doors open at 5:30pm and event commences at 6pm. This event is hybrid event see the "Code Katas [Virtual ]with Seattle JS Hackers" event page for Zoom link. Code Katas are a fun way to do coding exercises, inanylanguage you want. It's a good practice to keep increasing your skills as a coder. You can practice the same kata over and over to continue improving, get feedback from others, and move on to more difficult problems to solve. This will be a structured event where we will present the kata, and how to practice them, then everyone works to solve the problem on your own computer, get help from neighbors and mentors, and see how others solve the same problem! 5:30 - code ninjas arrive and socialize5:45 - food arrives (Sponsored by SEEKOUT)6:00 - intro, present format and prep6:10 - round 1 - warm up6:45 - round 2 - challenge yourself!8:00 - wrap up We organize coding sessions at venues in Seattle each week. Our sessions encourage peer ideation, knowledge sharing, new champions for causes and projects, and a heightened sense of community. If you have a cool project, work on it with us! This is a perfect time to start your code ninja career! We have a wide range of experience levels, and some of us love to teach (because you usually learn something when you teach, right?) So don't be afraid. Come on over. Seattle JS Hackers is a space for judgement-free learning and collaboration. We seek to support and encourage our members in a positive way; even negative feedback should be offered constructively and with respectful words. Please feel free to share your experiences with others (e.g., product, company, passion, recruitment opportunity) if asked, but save your sales pitches for other events. Remember, we are here to grow, learn, hack, and help each other! Join the Seattle JS Hackers Slack Group to keep the discussions going!https://join.slack.com/t/seattlejshackers/shared_invite/enQtMzYzMDcwNzQ3Nzk0LTcxZDI5NjA1MjIwYzdkYjQ5ZDhhYjVlNzg1MjljZTg5NjU1YTRlYzhjMjNiZTQ0Y2NkMGRkOTQ2N2Q2N2VjYzU

items.title: Seattle Makers Game Night!
items.description: Join us for our first Seattle Makers Game Night where we promote the development and creation of maker projects and games of all kinds. Do you have a project you’ve been working on that you want to show off and play-test? Bring it on in! Anything game related we are celebrating tonight: puzzles, arcade cabinets, custom chess pieces-this is a night for you! No project to show off? No worries! Come play games, hang out with good friends and build new like-minded connections. This event is open to all ages 11 and up (participants aged 16 and under require a legal guardian present), so bring your family and friends, and let’s make this a memorable night! Where is it:Seattle Makers, 3012 16th Ave W, Seattle, WACost:Free for members, $10 suggested donation for non-members. We can't wait to see what you bring! 1 attendee 1 attendee

items.title: Electronics and Robotics Meetup
items.description: In early recognition of Pi Day this year, we will be featuring some demos of the Raspberry Pi Pico that you can play with. If you've ever been curious about what microcontrollers like the Pico can do for you, stop by and explore! Do you have an electronics or robotics project that you keep putting off? Join us every second Tuesday of the month for our Electronics and Robotics Meetup to get it done! This is a great opportunity for show and tell, and to meet and learn from other electronics makers in the community. And if you're stuck, our resident electronics maketeer and Arduino 101 instructor will be around to help out. Whatever level from total beginner to advanced, we are here to help you. The meetup will run for 2 hours but feel free to drop in for just a question or the whole time. Cost:Free for members,$10 suggested donationfor non-members Whom it’s for:Anyone aged 11+ (youth 11-17 must have a guardian present). What we’ll provide:Soldering workstations; plenty of parts, modules and components available for purchase +4

items.description: Do you have an electronics or robotics project that you keep putting off? Join us every second Tuesday of the month for our Electronics and Robotics Meetup to get it done! This is a great opportunity for show and tell, and to meet and learn from other electronics makers in the community. And if you're stuck, our resident electronics maketeer and Arduino 101 instructor will be around to help out. Whatever level from total beginner to advanced, we are here to help you. The meetup will run for 2 hours but feel free to drop in for just a question or the whole time. Cost:Free for members,$10 suggested donationfor non-members Whom it’s for:Anyone aged 11+ (youth 11-17 must have a guardian present). What we’ll provide:Soldering workstations; plenty of parts, modules and components available for purchase 1 attendee 1 attendee

items.title: Bouldering
items.location: Seattle Bouldering Project, Poplar, Seattle, WA
items.description: Join us for bouldering, any amount of experience is welcome! This will be a weekly event happening every Wednesday night. This event will begin at 7:30pm until the gym closes at 11:00pm. Feel free to arrive and leave at any time. Day passes: $25+taxShow rentals: $4+tax 10 day and monthly passes are also available if you plan to come regularly. You can find more info on their website.https://boulderingproject.com/

items.title: The Seattle Spanish Society Weekly Meetup
items.location: Saint John's Bar and Eatery, Seattle, WA
items.description: Hola, Bienvenidos! NEW LOCATION AS OF JANUARY 2022! Welcome to our Sunday meeting. Thank you for your interest in practicing Spanish with us. This group has been a great success. Many have established long lasting amistades that extend in to social events outside the group. We have become una gran familia. Our meeting time is at 6:00 pm. Many of our members are on Latin culture time and therefore arrive late. Please introduce yourself when you arrive. Our meetings vary in length. Many stay until 10 pm. You are welcome to arrive and leave at any time. Our group consists of native speakers from many nationalities and all Spanish levels. If you are not fluent no hay problema you will find our members to be helpful and patient with you. Due to this event being a weekly meeting. Los organizadores may not attend all scheduled events. They would like for you to still have this opportunity in spite of their absence. However our members will be feliz to welcome you and introduce you to the group. For the Sunday meetings only you must be 21 and over due to bar regulations. Nos vemos el Domingo! Your organizers “Entre los individuos, como entre las naciones, el respeto al derecho ajeno es la paz” Benito Juarez +5

items.title: Board Games in Spanish!
items.location: Stoup Brewing - Capitol Hill, Seattle, WA
items.description: ¡Vamos a jugar juegos de mesa en español! GAMES* The World Game (Card Game) - Geography-based competition of quick wits and global knowledge (The country names are in Spanish.)* Manzanas con Manzanas (Apples to Apples in Spanish) Please consider bringing a game or two of your own. Some of us will be grabbing dinner nearby at 6pm. There are lots of great restaurants depending on the size of our group, including Korean, Chinese, and Mexican. NOTE: If you plan to join for dinner, please bring cash or download the Venmo app. This makes splitting the check easier for larger parties. This event is being cross-posted. Please also RSVP on the Seattle Language & Culture:https://www.meetup.com/seattle-language-culture-meetup/

Pancake Paddle #92
items.description: Pancake Paddle #92, Sunday, April 7th, 9AM. We'll be gathering in the lobby of the Swedish Club between 8:45AM and 9AM. At 9AM sharp we will go downstairs to Stockholm Hall and have a delicious Swedish pancake breakfast ($13) to the accompaniment of live Scandinavian folk music. At 9:45AM we will depart for the short walk down the Crocket Street stairs to the NWOC dock and start the paddle at 10:15AM. If you plan on renting your paddle craft, the most convenient option is the NWOC located on the dock we launch from. More info on NWOC hourly rentals at this link https://www.nwoc.com/rental/ From a logistics standpoint, rather than parking at the Swedish Club it is easier to first park at the NWOC dock at Crocket Street & Westlake--plenty of free parking--then walk up the stairs and one block south (left at the top of the stairs) to the Swedish Club at 1920 Dexter Ave N. Please dress and equip appropriately for whatever conditions we encounter on the lake. See you then! ***Anyone interested in volunteering at the Swedish Club Pancake Breakfast, you can do so by emailing Stacy Martens at stacey@swedishclubnw.org or call 206-283-1090. You don't need to be a member and there is a free breakfast in it for you, in addition to volunteering alongside a group of fun people. But make sure you volunteer for the early shift so you don't miss the paddle. And make sure to come to the kitchen and say hello to me. I'll be frying Swedish pancakes on the big grill. ***While you're on the NWOC dock be sure to check out their deals & specials on kayak & SUP gear https://www.nwoc.com/shop/ and their classes & trips https://www.nwoc.com/classes/default.asp?page=classes___________________________________________________ABOUT THE LAKE UNION PANCAKE PADDLE Eat Swedish pancakes. Then paddle. Beginners are most welcome. If you don't own a kayak, SUP or canoe, they can be rented by the hour at the dock we launch from. This group is open to all paddle craft (kayaks, SUPs, canoes, inflatables, dragon boats, etc.) and gathers regularly at 9AM on the first Sundays of every month in the lobby of the Swedish Club which is open to the public for their monthly Swedish pancake breakfasts. We enjoy the ten million dollar view and have a Swedish pancake breakfast together to the accompaniment of live Scandinavian folk music. Then we take the short walk down to the dock and leisurely paddle for an hour or so on the placid urban waters of Lake Union, the most unique lake in the world--home to Academy award winning movies, amazing houseboats, historic vessels & sunken battleships, storied Olympic champions, Native American history, stupendous infrastructure, a surprising amount of wildlife and the birthplace of the Boeing Airplane Co. We also do "Special Edition" paddles on the lakes and rivers of Western & Central Washington and on Puget's Sound, the Pacific Coast and the San Juans. Special Edition paddles often have no onsite rental availability. +4
